metadata.title: Prediction of the virus incubation period for COVID-19 and future outbreaks

body_text.text: Abstract 49

A crucial factor in mitigating respiratory viral outbreaks is early determination of the duration of the 50 incubation period and, accordingly, the required quarantine time for potentially exposed individuals. 51

Here, we explore different genomic features of RNA viruses that correlate with the incubation times and 52 provide a predictive model that accurately estimates the upper limit incubation time for diverse viruses 53
including SARS-CoV-2, and thus, could help control future outbreaks. 54 55 56 57
Main Text 58

The recent outbreak of the novel SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus and the resulting COVID-19 disease has led to 59 an unprecedented worldwide emergency 1 . Per World Health Organization (WHO) recommendations, 60 numerous countries have taken severe preventive measures to combat and stem the spread of the 61 virus. A key effective measure recommended by the WHO in viral outbreaks is enforcing a period of 62 quarantine on individuals that are suspected to have come in contact with the causative agent until they 63 are proven clean of infection 2,3 . The length of the quarantine typically depends on the time from virus 64 exposure to the emergence of symptoms, i.e. the incubation period. The duration of the incubation 65 period is specific to the causative virus 4 . Underestimation of the incubation time could lead to infected 66 individuals being prematurely released from quarantine and spreading the disease, whereas 67 overestimation can have a debilitating economic impact and cause detrimental psychological effects 5 . 68
Therefore, knowledge of the upper limit of a virus incubation period is crucial to effectively combat and 69 prevent outbreaks while minimizing the negative consequences of the quarantine. 70 71

The length of the incubation period varies both across and within virus families 4 . To our knowledge, 72 genomic features (if any) that correlate with the incubation time are currently unknown. There is 73 therefore a vital need for methods to predict the incubation periods of emerging viruses. Such methods 74
can be deployed in future viral outbreaks for early, accurate inference of the incubation period and 75
immediate implementation of optimized quarantining interventions that will mitigate the spread of the 76 virus while minimizing the negative societal impact 6 . 77 78

Here, we analyzed different genomic characteristics of respiratory, non-segmented, single-strand RNA 79 (ssRNA) viruses and identified features that are predictive of the incubation time, and are generalizable 80 across virus families. Based on these features, we developed an elastic net regression model that 81

predicts virus incubation periods. We extensively validated the robustness of this model and the 82 selected features for the prediction of the incubation period across diverse viruses and virus families, to 83 enable accurate early estimation of the incubation period for future outbreaks. 84 85 We focused on non-segmented ssRNA viruses that cause respiratory infections, to minimize 86 confounders to the incubation period that could result from different genome structures and/or 87 different infected tissues and cell types. In total, we collected information for 14 viruses from 4 families. 88

Given that the quarantine time is defined as the upper limit of virus incubation time, we extracted the 89 upper estimates of the incubation periods for all viruses in the analyzed set (Supp. Table 1, see Methods  90 for details). We then curated 8 features that we hypothesized could be relevant for the incubation 91 period (Figure 1a ), based on the complete genome nucleotide sequences and within-population genome 92 alignments of all sequenced strains of each virus (Supp. Datasets 1 and 2, see Methods for details). 93
Analysis of the pairwise associations between these features (Fig. 1a) confirmed some previously 94

reported associations, such as the negative correlation between genome length and mutation rate 7 and 95 the positive correlation between GC content and codon adaptation index 8 (CAI) (Fig. 1b) . Strikingly, our 96 findings suggest that the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is substantially lower than that of other human 97 coronaviruses (CoV), including its closest human-infecting relative, SARS-CoV (with an average of 1.4e-3 98 and 7.8e-5 transitions per branch point per nucleotide for SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2, respectively, Fig.  99 1b, see Methods for details). Preliminary reports on SARS-CoV-2 genome evolution indicate a similar 100 trend 9 . 101 102 103 We then sought to select features to be used for a predictive model of the incubation time. To avoid 117

confounding the model with features that are primarily driven by virus family, we formally quantified 118 whether a given feature is significantly associated with the family identity. To this end, we applied two 119 complementary approaches, namely, analysis of variance (ANOVA) and an empirical, non-parametric 120 test, to estimate, for each feature, whether it varies more across virus families than within each family 121 (see Methods for details). The results obtained with the two approaches were equivalent, 122
demonstrating that half of the considered features vary more between families than within families, and 123
therefore may confound the model (Fig. 1c) . We denote such features family-specific. By contrast, we 124

found that the incubation time was not significantly associated with virus family (Fig. 1d) , supporting 125 selection of features that are not family-specific to train a model; we denote such features family-126

generic. Four other features were found to be family-generic: GC content of the virus genome; variance 127 of the number of different nucleotides observed per position in the alignment of the virus strains; 128 number of protein-coding genes in the virus genome; codon adaptation index (CAI) (Fig. 1e) . Thus, these 129
four features were included in the model. 130 131

Next, we sought to divide the analyzed dataset into training and test sets. To maintain a large enough 132 independent test set, we trained an elastic net model on the 7 human-infecting viruses of the family 133

Coronaviridae (Fig. 2a) , using the four family-generic features. We found that this model, which was 134 trained on a single viral family, generalized well to viruses from the three other families (Fig. 2b) . The 135 test mean absolute error was 1.63 days (Fig. 2b ), attesting to a close estimation of the upper limit of the 136 incubation time in an independent data set. Moreover, the model predictions strongly correlated with 137 the ranks of the assigned incubation periods in the test set (Spearman's ρ = 0.91, p-value = 0.005). 138

Specifically, for the virus with the longest known incubation period, measles, the longest incubation 139 time, 9.7 days, was predicted. Although measles was assigned an upper limit incubation period of 14 140 days in our data, the majority of the available reports are indeed in the range of 9-12 days 10 . The second 141 longest incubation period was also correctly assigned, to respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), with a 142 prediction of 9.1 days, compared to an assigned period of 8 days in our data. For parainfluenza 1-3, the 143 model predicted 7.3, 4.9, and 6.2 days, respectively, closely approximating the assigned 6 days. 144

Metapneumovirus was similarly accurately predicted to have a 6.5 days incubation period, within half a 145 day of its assigned 6 days. Finally, the shortest incubation time predicted was correctly assigned to 146 rhinovirus, with a prediction of a 1.2 day incubation period. Although rhinovirus was assigned a 4 day 147 incubation period in our data, most of the cases show symptoms within one day 11 . 148 149 Exploration of the model indicated that the strongest predictive features were the number of protein-150 coding genes and GC content, with higher values in either feature corresponding to a longer incubation 151 time (Fig. 2c) . Elucidation of the mechanisms behind these associations will require extensive 152 experimental work. A straightforward, even if, likely, over-simplified explanation could be that the larger 153 number of genes to be translated by the virus lengthens its replication cycle, under the assumption that 154 the number of translation initiation events and/or subgenomic RNAs that need to be transcribed are 155 rate-limiting factors in virus reproduction. Similarly, a higher GC content leads to the formation of 156 stable secondary structures in the virus RNA, with higher kinetic barriers that the ribosome then needs 157 to disrupt during translation, resulting in longer translation times 12 . Thus, one possible explanation for 158 the association between the number of protein-coding genes and the GC content and longer incubation 159 periods is that the longer cumulative translation time extends the replication cycle and consequently, 160 the incubation period. Alternatively or additionally, extra genes could contribute to more complex 161

interactions of the virus with the host organism, resulting in a longer incubation times. In particular, the 162 highly virulent coronaviruses with long characteristic incubation periods are known to encode 163 additional, accessory proteins compared to low virulence viruses that have shorter incubation times 13,14 . 164
The accessory genes are dispensable for virus reproduction in cell culture and have been implicated in 165

virus-host interactions 15 . Recent preliminary analysis has shown that some of these additional genes 166 encode proteins containing distinct immunoglobulin-like domains, which is compatible with roles in 167
interactions with the immune system of the host 16 . 168 169

To assess the robustness of the selected features, we tested models trained with different partitioning 170 of the data into train and test sets. We found that these changes did not significantly change the 171 performance of the models, further attesting to the robustness of the signal obtained using the four 172

family-generic features (Fig. 2d) . By contrast, a model trained with family-specific features does not 173 generalize to the test set, and one trained using a mixture of family-generic and family-specific features 174 disregards the latter by nullifying their coefficients (Supp. Fig. 1) , further demonstrating the efficacy of 175 relying on family-generic features only. The coefficients assigned to the family-generic features did not 176 vary substantially across different training sets, confirming that the method is not particularly sensitive 177

to the data used for training (Fig. 2c) . Nevertheless, the high performance of the model that is trained 178 exclusively on CoV seems to suggest that this virus family provides a good representation of the 179 incubation period, and/or that training on a single family is preferable given the small dataset and the 180 possibility of confounding effects. recent reports indicate that 97.5% of patients who will develop symptoms do so within a 95% 202 confidence interval of 8.2-15.6 days 17 . Despite having been trained on an imbalanced training set, the 203 model predicts an incubation period of 8.8 days for SARS-CoV-2, correctly placing SARS-CoV-2 in the 204 upper range of incubation periods, well within the confidence interval, and predicting an incubation 205 period duration during which the vast majority of symptomatic patients will have shown symptoms 17 . 206

Clearly, this estimate could have been useful in mitigating the COVID-19 pandemic ( Fig. 2e; similar  207 analysis for the other CoV is provided in Supp. Fig. 2 File 2) . Phylogenetic trees were generated for each virus based on the alignment using 222
FastTree 21,22 with the "-nt" parameter. 223 224
Incubation period assignment 225

The incubation time for each of the 14 viruses was collected from literature (Supp . Table 1 ). As 226 incubation periods vary, where possible, the upper limit was used, and a consensus of reports was 227 followed. We note that there are small variations in reports of the incubation times, and the assigned 228

values represent the best approximation as explained below. Changing the assigned incubation times 229 within the range of reports maintains a similarly high performance of the trained model (Supp. Fig. 2 ). 230 231
The rationale for the selected incubation times was as follows: 232
a. 229E-CoV, HKU1-CoV, NL63-CoV and OC43-CoV. For these coronaviruses, which are causative 233 agents of common colds, a 3 day incubation period was assigned, following the majority of 234

reports 23 accounting for selection bias, by detecting the ancestral base for every base in the genome for 266 every non-leaf node in the tree using maximum parsimony. Then, at each branch point, the 267 transitions between both sides of the branch were counted, and the average count was then 268 divided by the length of the genome for the final estimate. Evaluation of the specificity of the features for virus families 275

We sought to evaluate, for each feature, whether it is associated with the identity of the virus family 276 which would be a potential confounder to the model. We hence searched for features whose variance 277 within each virus family was not significantly smaller than its overall variance. To this end, each feature 278 was evaluated using two methods. 279 280

The first method is a one-way Analysis of variance (ANOVA). One-way ANOVA tests the null hypothesis 281 that the means of the measurement variable are the same for the different categories of data, against 282 the alternative hypothesis that they are not all the same. Hence, lower assigned p-values signify that the 283 null hypothesis is rejected, and that different viral families have different population means with respect 284 to each feature. We therefore consider features assigned with a P-value greater than 0.05, for which we 285 could accept the null hypothesis, and could not conclude that the feature mean was associated with the 286 viral family. The ANOVA test was implemented in Python using the f_oneway function in the SciPy 33 287
package. 288 289

The ANOVA test assumes that the samples are independent, taken from normally distributed 290 populations with equal standard deviations between the groups. These assumptions, that must be 291 satisfied for the associated p-value to be valid, are not guaranteed and are difficult to evaluate. We 292 hence implemented a second, empirical test, which is not parametric and does not rely on any 293

assumptions. This empirical test evaluates, for a given feature, if its variance within virus families is 294 smaller than would be observed by random assignment of families to viruses. We reason that a feature 295 which is associated with the virus family would have significantly smaller variance within the true family 296 assignment than within a random family assignment. The null hypothesis is that the variance of the 297 features within each family is similar to the variance across families, and the alternative hypothesis is 298 that the variance of the features within each family is smaller than the variance across families. To 299 perform the empirical test, the feature variance within each virus family is calculated and averaged. 300

Next, the feature values are randomly permuted 1,000 times and the same calculation is performed, to 301 generate a null distribution. Let the number of times the variance of the permuted values is less than 302 the variance of the real values be . The p-value is calculated as ( + 1)/(1000 + 1). Thus, a lower p-303 value indicates that the feature's within-family variance is smaller than our null expectation. We search 304

for features with a p-value greater than 0.05, for which we conclude that the variance within the actual 305 families is not smaller than that within randomly assigned families. This evaluation does not necessarily 306
indicate that the family-specific features are poor predictors, rather, that, with the data available, it 307
would not be possible to discern whether the signal from these features is primarily driven by the 308 variation between virus families. 309 310
Elastic Net Model 311

The elastic net method 34 is a generalization of LASSO using Ridge regression shrinkage, where the naïve 312 estimator ̂i s a minimizer of the criterion ( 1 , 2 , ) by: 313 314 ̂= ( ( 1 , 2 , )) = (|| − || 2 + + 1 || || 1 + 2 || || 2 ) 315 316
for any fixed,

FIGREF0.text: Genomic features of ssRNA viruses causing respiratory infections. (a) Pairwise correlation 104 matrix across all features. A description of feature construction is given in the Methods section. Each 105 circle indicates Spearman's ρ between two features. The colors represent the rank-correlation 106 coefficients (red indicates positive correlation and blue indicates negative correlation), and the circle 107 sizes correspond to significance (p-value), where significant correlations (p-value <0.05) are circled in 108 black. (b) Scatter plots illustrating the relationships between features across four virus families. (c) 109 Estimation of the features association with the virus family, based on p-values (-log scaled) from two 110 tests applied (see Methods for details). The cutoff (p-value = 0.05) is indicated with a dashed line. Lower 111 values correspond to features that are not significantly associated with a virus family. (d) Boxplot and 112 overlaid dot plot of the incubation periods across viral families. (e) Dot plots of different features across 113 Log

FIGREF1.text: Assessment of the elastic net model for virus incubation time prediction. (a) A scatter plot of 185 the incubation periods of the CoV training set compared to the model predictions, with the model R 2 in 186 the upper left corner. (b) A scatter plot of the incubation periods of the test set compared to the model 187 predictions. The box in the bottom right corner contains: Spearman's ρ between the predictions and the 188 true values; the P-value of the Spearman's ρ; the model R 2 ; the mean absolute error (MAE). (c) A 189 heatmap of the coefficients of each feature using different training sets. (d) A bar plot of the model 190 performance metrics using different subsets of training and testing data, with the number of samples in 191 the testing data for each subset indicated. (e) A scatter plot of the incubation periods of the test set 192 compared to the model predictions when SARS-CoV-2 is left out of training. The box in the top left 193 corner shows the model's performance metrics. 194 195To evaluate the utility of our model, we examined how this method could have performed during the 196 early stages of the current COVID-19 pandemic. To this end, we removed SARS-CoV-2 from the training 197 data and trained the model on the remaining 6 CoV only, with the caveat that this training set is poorly 198balanced as it contains only 2 viruses with incubation times longer than 3 days, and therefore, might 199 underestimate when predicting viruses with long incubation times. The incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 200 is still being determined, with the recommended quarantine time conservatively set at 14 days although

FIGREF2.text: 269 g. Average and variance of the changes in each position of the alignment. The change in alignment 270 position is defined as the number of different values observed in each position of the virus 271 alignment, divided by the number of strains in the alignment. The average and variance of these 272 values are used as features. 273 274

TABREF3.text: non-negative 1 , 2 . Elastic net was chosen because it has characteristics of both LASSO 317 and Ridge regression, which are controlled by the penalties coefficients, thus outperforming other 318 regularization and variable selection approaches 34 . 319 320 The elastic net model was constructed in Python using the scikit-learn 35 ElasticNet function with default 321 parameters. The features were standardized before training, with the same standardization parameters 322 used in training applied to test data before prediction. 323 324 Data availability 325 Virus genome sequence alignments used for this analysis are provided as supplementary information. 326 Our model, features and the accompanying code are available at 329 https://github.com/noamaus/incubation-model. 330 331
